content.description:
(Lat: 47.283089, Lon: -71.430776, km 24.5, elev 1150 ft) The alpine setting gives this route a secluded feel. Short sections of WI 2-3 ice interspersed with snow-wallowing. The route gets sun most of the afternoon, which helps you forget about the approach you just endured. P1 WI2 30m. In the woods. P2 3rd 100-150m elev 1400ft. Walk/tunnel/burrow up through the snow. P3, P4 WI2-3 85m elev 1700ft. Short steps of ice - belay mid-way up on screws, and continue. P5 60m. More wallowing in snow. P6 WI3 55m. 70 degree. P7 WI2 55m. Descent: Use the trees to climber's left to rappel (we found no slings in 2021). Double ropes will save time, but the descent can be made on a single rope. Location:  km 24.5, east side of the Jacques-Cartier river From the Pont-Blanc warming hut (km 18, 47.228114, -71.409214), continue along the Chemin de la vallée trail until about km 24.5, elevation 900m. There is a big sign for the Ekwatek canoe put-in, and the climb is visible high up in the trees on the east (right) side. Wallow from the trail straight up over ankle-busting talus to the climb, elevation 1150m (30-45min, depending on snow depth). Standard rack of ice screws.
Most belays (except top of P3) can be made from trees, so go light on the screws.

A long ice slab over 200m gives access to a large vertical pillar of 35m. The rappels can be done on trees or on threads. This route is 17,3 km from the parking. It is a major route that should not be taken lightly. Its access and its commitment transform this ascent into a real expedition. The route is located in the backcountry. It is mandatory to obtain an access permit from the SEPAQ.

Une longue dalle de glace sur plus de 200m donne accès à un grand pilier vertical de 35m. Les rappels peuvent se faire sur arbres ou sur lunules. Cette voie est a 17,3 km du stationnement. C’est une voie d’envergure qu’il ne faut pas prendre à la légère. Son accès et son engagement transforme cette ascension en une véritable expédition. La voie se situe dans l’arrière-pays. Il est obligatoire d’obtenir un permis d’accès à la SEPAQ.



The route is located at kilometer 27.3 on the main road of the Jacques-Cartier Park. The road is cleared of snow until you reach the reception area at kilometer 10, so you must ski or snowshoe the remaining 17.3 km in powder snow.

La voie se situe au kilomètre 27,3 sur le chemin principal du Parc de la Jacques-Cartier. Le chemin est déneigé jusqu’à l’accueil au kilomètre 10. Il faut donc parcourir les 17,3km restant à ski ou en raquette dans la poudreuse.


Ice screws. Vis à glace

climbs.name: L'Autoroute
climbs.fa: Louis Babin, Mario Savard, Yves Tremblay, 1981

content.description:
(Lat: 47.252624, Long: -71.428104, km 21)
The most accessible route in the valley, just 11km from the visitor center.

A reliable wide field of ice and steep snow.

Rappel on trees.



The first major flow on the west bank 3km beyond the Pont-Blanc warming hut at km 21 on the Chemin de la Vallée.

From the warming hut, your firs decision is whether to follow the trail on the east bank, and cross the river (consider harnessing up in the warming hut and using a rope. Unbuckle your pack and understand water rescue), or to cross the Pont-Blanc bridge and break trail up the west bank of the river for 3 km.

Ice screws

Just 30 minutes drive north of Quebec city - and a long approach on skis - lie some remote, long, and infrequently visited routes stretching a few hundred meters up the valley walls of the Jacques-Cartier (J-C) river. The routes are serious affairs, providing seclusion and an alpine feel. 
  
 Bureaucracy and fees: 
 J-C, like other SEPAQs, charges a daily access fee (currently $8.50 per person in 2021 for day use, plus $15 per over-night in the backcountry). Fees can be paid at the park gate (or online during COVID restrictions). 
  
 In order to climb in the J-C SEPAQ, (1) you must submit one backcountry access permit form per climber, (2) you must submit one liability waiver per team, containing the signatures of each climber. [Bureaucracy is the status-quo in the SEPAQ world.] SEPAQ asks you to submit the forms by email 7 days in advance (however, they seem to process the forms within a day, and imply they will accommodate shorter timescales on a best effort basis).  
  
 Despite the bureaucratic ridiculousness (who knows what they're going to climb further in advance than a reliable weather forecast??), the individuals processing the forms are friendly and efficient. They will also help ensure no more than one team is targeting each route on a given day (which rarely happens for these remote climbs). 
 If, for some unforeseen reason, you end up targeting a climb you do not have a permit for, be sure to give the right away to a team that does have a permit (first come, first served is not the ethic for this area). 
 For more info, see:  sepaq.com/quoi-faire/expedi… 
  
 Huts: 
 As of 2021, the only backcountry refuge that is exists along the route is the refuge Sautauriski at km 12.5 along the Chemin de la vallée (2.5 km from the visitor center). It can be booked through the SEPAQ (in 2021 due to COVID, this does not show up on the SEPAQ webpage, but is available by phoning the reservation center).
